thread.title: Jobless claims rise to 244,000, running at lowest in four decades
thread.title_full: Jobless claims rise to 244,000, running at lowest in four decades | Washington Examiner

author: Joseph Lawler
title: Jobless claims rise to 244,000, running at lowest in four decades
text:
New claims for unemployment benefits are running at the lowest level in over four decades, the Department of Labor reported Thursday, in a sign that the labor market recovery is still underway.
Jobless claims rose to 244,000 in the second full week of February, in line with forecasters' expectations, but even with that slight increase the average for new claims over the past month dropped to 241,000, the lowest level since 1973.
Then, under President Richard Nixon, the U.S. workforce was just over 90 million, versus the nearly 160 million strong it is today.
Low claims, which are seasonally adjusted, are a good sign for the economy. Few people applying for benefits at state agencies suggests that layoffs are relatively infrequent. Investors and policymakers watch the closely jobless claims numbers closely because they provide a frequently-updated gauge of the health of the jobs market.
  Low jobless claims are one of the economic statistics that most strongly suggests that the U.S. economy is improving, amid a number of other more mixed signals.
At 4.8 percent in January, the unemployment rate is already near where Federal Reserve officials think it would be if the economy is fully healthy. In recent weeks, several Fed officials have suggested that the economy is near full employment, justifying a move to raise interest rates in the months ahead.
